results.title: Warlords II Scenario Builder for DOS
results.material_description: Floppy disk videogame. Three 3 1/2 inch floppy disks, CD-ROM, CD jewel case, registration card, subscription card, catalogue and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Warlords II: Scenario Builder allows for an improved amount of customization to the base Warlords II game. These include the ability to edit the map, add new items, write descriptive text, create new unit and city graphics using a pixel editor and even change specific unit characteristics. 24 new scenarios also come with the pack, including ones that draw from historic sources like Medieval England to more far-fetched situations, like an alien invasion.
results.description: Warlords II: Scenario Builder allows for an improved amount of customization to the base Warlords II game. results.title: [John Anderson Home Movie Collection]
results.material_description: 7x 16mm film assorted newsreels and home movie. Can of 9.5mm assorted smaller reels. Focus on Ballarat. Family collection by filmmaker John (Jack) Anderson (dec.)
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

The collection is filmed on 16mm and 9.5mm film and the films can sometimes be a bit damaged and shaky.

results.title: [Cinesound Review: Royal Tour Concludes]
results.creator_credit: Peter Bell, William M. Carty and Cinesound
results.brief_description:
This film is a Cinesound Review, a news broadcast that covered significant social, cultural and political events in Australia. The newsreel shows the final leg of the 1970 Royal Tour with Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh and Princess Anne, for the bicentenary celebrations of the arrival of Captain James Cook in Australia in 1770.

The film shows the royal family arriving in Brisbane, Queensland, on the Royal Yacht Britannia, where they are greeted by crowds of people in hundreds of boats on the river. It shows the family attending various events, including a welcome at Parliament House, theatre shows and a children’s parade at Lang Park, or Brisbane Stadium.

Princess Anne visits a sheep station at Cunnamulla, Queensland, while Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip visit the mines at Mount Isa, Queensland.

The film shows bicentenary celebrations in Cooktown, Queensland, and Botany Bay, New South Wales. These celebrations include a speech by the Queen and re-enactments of Captain James Cook’s arrival in Australia in 1770, with interactions with Aboriginal Australian people.

The film continues with fireworks over Sydney Harbour; an ANZAC Day march in Canberra, Australian Capital Territory; Prince Philip playing polo with a local team; and the opening of the international terminal at Sydney Airport, from which the royal family departs.

group_siblings.title: [Around Australia with Movietone; Gt. Barrier Reef; Sporting Highlights; Skiing; 1949 Melbourne Cup]
[John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 4 and Reel 5] [excerpts]

results.title: [Cinesound Review 1950-1965]
results.brief_description:
This film contains excerpts from Cinesound Review, a news broadcast that covered significant social, cultural and political events in Australia. The film features a number of different clips from newsreels between 1950 and 1965.

The first section, titled ‘1950 Melbourne Cup’, shows the horse race at Flemington Racecourse, photographed by Ron Horner. The film includes close-ups of people in the crowd, and commentary of the race as Comic Court wins. This is followed by a section titled ‘Scone Rodeo: Bronchos (sic) on the Bust’, featuring footage of a horse rodeo in Scone, New South Wales.

The third section, titled ‘Fur Flies: Battling Budgerigar K.O.’s Cat’ features a playfight between two pets, a ginger cat and a budgerigar. In the fourth section we see ANZAC Day parades in Melbourne and Sydney, preluded by the title ‘ANZAC: Nation’s Homage’.

The fifth section is titled ‘Skiing: Day and Night Fun at Mt. Buller’, with commentary by David Low. It features children learning how to ski and social activities in the resorts, including bands and dancing. This is followed by an excerpt called ‘Clark Well Ahead’, showing the motorcar race at the 1965 British Grand Prix, won by Jim Clark.

The film ends with a cartoon called ‘Local Boy Makes Good: A Story with a Moral’ and three feature film trailers: ‘The Counterfeit Traitor’ (1962), ‘Pollyanna’ (1960) and ‘Mein Kampf’ (1960).
results.description:
This film contains excerpts from Cinesound Review, a news broadcast that covered significant social, cultural and political events in Australia. The film features a number of different clips from newsreels between 1950 and 1965.

The first section, titled ‘1950 Melbourne Cup’, shows the horse race at Flemington Racecourse, photographed by Ron Horner. The film includes close-ups of people in the crowd, and commentary of the race as Comic Court wins. This is followed by a section titled ‘Scone Rodeo: Bronchos (sic) on the Bust’, featuring footage of a horse rodeo in Scone, New South Wales.

The third section, titled ‘Fur Flies: Battling Budgerigar K.O.’s Cat’ features a playfight between two pets, a ginger cat and a budgerigar. In the fourth section we see ANZAC Day parades in Melbourne and Sydney, preluded by the title ‘ANZAC: Nation’s Homage’.

The fifth section is titled ‘Skiing: Day and Night Fun at Mt. Buller’, with commentary by David Low. It features children learning how to ski and social activities in the resorts, including bands and dancing. This is followed by an excerpt called ‘Clark Well Ahead’, showing the motorcar race at the 1965 British Grand Prix, won by Jim Clark.

The film ends with a cartoon called ‘Local Boy Makes Good: A Story with a Moral’ and three feature film trailers: ‘The Counterfeit Traitor’ (1962), ‘Pollyanna’ (1960) and ‘Mein Kampf’ (1960).

results.title: [5 Couleurs de France]
results.brief_description:
This film is a TV Color Paris production titled ‘5 Couleurs de France’, which translates as ‘5 Colours of France’. It features a presentation on the 1967 Cannes Film Festival, with a voiceover spoken in English. The 1967 festival was the 20th anniversary of the festival. The film includes snippets of interviews with Claude Lelouche, Sylva Koscina, Robert Bresson, Monica Vitti and Vanessa Redgrave, translated by the narrator.

It also contains footage of film stars and directors at the festival, particularly at the awards ceremony. These include guest of honour Brigitte Bardot, award presenter Virna Lisi and winner of the Palme d’Or (then known as the Grand Prix International du Festival) Michelangelo Antonioni, for his film ‘Blow Up’.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

results.title: Beautiful Ballarat
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

The collection is filmed on 16mm and 9.5mm film and the films can sometimes be a bit damaged and shaky.

This film presents scenes from in and around central and suburban Ballarat in the 1940s to 1950s.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 title card “Beautiful Ballarat”
00:00:29:00 1950s tramcar passing old Ballarat post office on Sturt Street, Ballarat
00:00:58:00 FJ holden Radio Cabs lined up
00:09:13:00 snowfall 1940s Ballarat town centre and surrounds
00:11:03:00 odd looking snowman
00:11:14:00 snowball fight between grown men with some funny ham acting
00:11:26:00 nice shot of RADIO CABS neon sign lit up at night
00:11:30:00 lights on buildings celebrating the municipality of Ballarat 1855–1955 “100”

results.title: HYPER/ECHO
results.creator_credit: Andrew Gleeson, Cecile Richard and Firepit Collective
results.brief_description: HYPER/ECHO points to our relationship with technology and the digital world, how brittle and ephemeral – often by design – its infrastructure really is, and to the fundamental human desire to preserve and pass down knowledge, even when buildings crumble down, languages wane, and hyperlinks break.

results.title: Shinjuku Thief Remixes
results.brief_description: Supported by the City of Melbourne COVID-19 arts grants, this project engaged composers, sound designers and video editors to experiment and remix ACMI archive footage. A bold piece of music inspires a conceptual pairing from the collection, the elements of which are then carefully assembled into a microstructural puzzle of tight gestural relationships.
